text: on a busy morning commuters cross the
yangon River as they enter Yangon
Myanmar largest city and former capital
they pass British colonial buildings
these buildings survived devastating
cyclones the Japanese bombs of World War
two and in many cases decades of neglect
what we have is one of the last 1930
twentieth-century cityscapes left in all
of Asia and I think that's valuable in
itself and I think this is something
where if not now 10 20 years in the
future if we destroy it will regret it
fat man who is founder and chairman of
the Yangon Heritage Trust
he's also the grandson of Athan the
Burmese diplomat who is the United
Nations secretary-general in the 1960s
he's concerned his city's architectural
heritage will be destroyed in the rush
to build new hotels and office towers so
his group is pushing the government to
enact preservation laws one of our main
ideas is that as the city modernizes if
we can protect a lot of this heritage
and build on it as well as having a
modern city we can have a one of the
most beautiful cities in the region as
well for decades when Myanmar was
controlled by brutal military regimes it
was one of the most isolated nations in
the world since introducing political
reforms in 2011 foreign investment is
flooding in and poor people here are
getting priced out I think we have to
also put it forefront the situation of
people especially low-income families
live downtown many of them can live
downtown
only because of rent control many of
them pay almost nothing to live in these

there are sixteen apartments this unit
alone has his four families more than 20
people
Tokyo has lived here all his life he
says if his family has to move they'll

because I think the worst thing that

maybe some rich people and I think we

Myanmar's attracting investment and aid

the roads are old and congested across
